title: Corbyn slams Boris Johnson for 'blatant and discriminatory' Voter ID law plan
text:

Jeremy Corbyn has slammed Boris Johnson for planning a "blatant and discriminatory" change to the law in a bid to make it harder for ethnic minorities and poor people to vote.

Tories unveiled plans for a new law which force voters to show a photo ID before being allowed to cast their ballot.

Defending the announcement the Government claimed that the lack of an election ID law was a "security risk", despite there being just a handful of examples of in-person voter fraud.

Speaking at an event to mark Black History Month, Mr Corbyn said: “These plans are clearly discriminatory and a blatant attempt by the Tories to suppress voters, deny people their democratic rights and rig the result of the next General Election .

“The people that the Tories are trying to stop voting will be disproportionately from ethnic minority backgrounds, and they will disproportionately be working-class voters of all ethnicities.

“We will not allow the Tories to shut down our democracy and shut ethnic minority voters out of our democracy by making it harder for people to vote."

(Image: PA)

Hundreds of people were denied their right to vote in last year’s local elections after ministers forced through a pilot scheme.

Some 3.5 million citizens in the UK do not have access to photo ID, and 11 million citizens do not have a passport or driving licence.

Government sources have suggested a “free” ID card would be made available to people who have none.

But the Electoral Commission has estimated such a card would cost £11 million to produce.

And it could make every election cost as much as £20 million more to administer.

Out of 44.6 million votes cast in the 2017 election, there were just 28 allegations of fraud that would be prevented by requiring ID to vote.

(Image: UK PARLIAMENTARY RECORDING UNIT HANDOUT/EPA-EFE/REX)

Dr Jess Garland, Director of Policy and Research at the Electoral Reform Society, said: “The Windrush scandal showed what can happen when millions of people who lack ID are shut out by thegovernment.

"BAME groups – as well as many young and elderly voters – are likely to be hard hit by this ‘show your papers’ policy.

“These plans risk excluding huge numbers of marginalised voters – including many elderly and BAME voters – from our democratic processes and risk undermining free and fair elections."

The PM’s official spokesman defended the move saying it was a "proportionate and reasonable step" to improve the security of the electoral system

He added that voter ID has run in Northern Ireland since 2003 “without any impact on the number of people who go and vote”.

But asked if the government could point to any evidence of widespread voter fraud at the ballot box, the spokesman did not.

Instead, he said: “I think the issue is ensuring the electoral process is as secure as possible."

A No10 spokesman said: “I’m not sure politically we’ll be taking messages about voter suppression from a party whose main mandate at the moment is to suppress the biggest vote in the democratic history of this country."
description: The Labour leader warned that the law would disproportionately target BAME and poorer voters
